awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research:  Detecting Financial Market Manipulation: An Integrated Data- and Model-Driven Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Financial stock market manipulators can profit illegally by misleading investors about market conditions. For example, in several recent incidents, manipulators successfully spoofed markets by inserting orders that deceived investors about supply or demand for the security. This kind of behavior has increased with the prevalence of algorithmic trading. It imposes substantial harm to the economy, by reducing the efficiency of capital allocation, and more seriously, threatening to compromise the integrity and stability of financial markets. Spoofing is difficult to detect because the underlying actions have legitimate purposes as well as nefarious ones. This project will apply innovative approaches to improve detection and deterrence of market manipulation.

The project will integrate data-driven methods, including calibration of detectors with normal background activity and extraction of manipulation signatures from enhanced time series, with model-based techniques for characterizing manipulation strategies based on strategic analysis of market microstructure. The key idea is to use simulation and optimization to generate successful manipulation strategies for trading models calibrated from available market data streams. These strategies will then be injected into the trading models, to produce enhanced data streams that include labeled manipulation activity. Having labeled activity enables the application of machine learning techniques to extract signatures of spoofing activity, which can be used to construct surveillance and audit algorithms. Methods produced in this project in conjunction with guidance on market design and regulation policy can contribute to reducing the threat from increasingly capable market manipulators.

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary project studied the problem of manipulation in financial markets, with an eye toward improving capabilities to detect and prevent manipulative activity. Market manipulation comes in many forms and can be described in many ways, but a good place to start is the definition from the United States Securities and Exchange Commission: “intentional conduct designed to deceive investors by controlling or artificially affecting the market for a security”. Conduct that would fall under this definition is quite prevalent, and probably has been as long as markets for financial securities have existed. Of special interest for this project was how manipulation practice has evolved with the advent of electronic markets and automated trading, and how it may yet evolve with sophisticated techniques from artificial intelligence.

One of our first tasks was to examine available market data for characteristic patterns of manipulation. We focused on spoofing, a common form of manipulation based on the placement of spurious orders: offers to trade that the spoofer has no intent to execute. The orders are placed to give the impression of demand (or supply, in the case of sell orders) in the market that does not really exist, and thereby push prices in a certain direction. The spoofer monitors closely and cancels the orders before they can be executed.

To complement the data analysis, we developed agent-based simulation models to generate and study manipulative behavior in a laboratory setting. A key result was the development of a computational model of spoofing, which demonstrated how the practice works and provides a basis for studying its effects and potential countermeasures. We showed that spoofing is possible whenever there are traders who base their decisions on market data. Interestingly, we found using game-theoretic analysis that it is rational to continue to employ market data for decision making (albeit in a hedged way) even when spoofers may be present, and so spoofing can be a profitable practice even in an informed setting.

Using this computational model, we studied potential ways to mitigate manipulation by hiding information. That is, we can reduce what the traders can see, which makes it harder for a manipulator to use this channel to mislead. We also showed that traders can be more robust to manipulation if they selectively ignore information on their own.

A next step was to explore the ability to learn manipulative strategies automatically. We demonstrated this in a scenario of benchmark manipulation, where the manipulator has an incentive to influence the price of one security in order to make profits on another security tied to the price of the first. The possibility of automated manipulation learning has major implications for financial regulation, particularly because most legal definitions of manipulation (e.g., the SEC definition quoted above) rely on the designs or intents of the manipulative trader. If the strategy is learned automatically, the people who run the strategy may try to claim they had no manipulative intent. The strategy just came up with this behavior on its own which happens to employ manipulative techniques incidentally.

The potential for automated generation of manipulative strategies is substantially increased by the advent of deep learning methods, particularly deep reinforcement learning, which is already widely adopted in the financial trading industry. We investigated the use of deep learning in this context, first by building a GAN (generalized adversarial network) capable of learning to generate realistic order streams. We then further employed techniques from adversarial machine learning to demonstrate the cat-and-mouse game between a regulator and manipulator: the former continually evolving models to detect manipulation, and the latter successfully learning how to evade the detectors. Finally, we developed initial capabilities using deep reinforcement learning for deriving manipulative strategies.

The project culminated in a draft report on the policy implications of AI and machine learning for manipulation, led by the project’s legal and policy experts and in collaboration with the project’s computer scientists. It describes limitations and gaps in current legal regimes, and proposes approaches for effective regulation.

The project’s research outcomes are reported in greater detail in a host of academic publications. Beyond the academic community, we have also been active in sharing our findings and results with practitioners, especially regulators in government and financial industry.
